channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 The New York Times Company

item.title: Drag Takes Off in the Philippines, a Bastion of Christianity
item.description: For many performers, drag is not only a cultural phenomenon, but also a political statement promoting social justice and gay rights.
item.dc:creator: Camille Elemia and Jes Aznar
item.media:description: Butterboy, a cafe in Quezon City, the Philippines, has started hosting drag shows.

item.title: Middle East Crisis: Israeli Airstrikes Hit Gaza City; Casualties Are Reported
item.description: The Israeli military said fighter jets had targeted “Hamas military infrastructure” at two sites. Gazan authorities reported multiple dead and said people were trapped under rubble.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Sheinbaum’s American Experience Offers Clues to Her Approach to U.S. Relations
item.description: The next Mexican president’s years of living in California provide insight into how she will handle key issues in Mexico-Washington ties.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.media:credit: César Rodríguez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Claudia Sheinbaum, who has strong ties to the United States, was elected this month to be the first female president of Mexico.

item.title: Pope’s Anti-Gay Slur Lays Bare Church’s Contradictions
item.description: The pope used homophobic slang and cautioned prelates about admitting gay men into seminaries. But ordination has also long been a refuge for gay faithful.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Elisabetta Povoledo
item.media:description: Pope Francis speaking on Wednesday during the weekly general audience at the Vatican.

item.title: Why Turkey Is Euro 2024’s Second Home Team
item.description: A soccer championship has doubled as a test of identity for millions of Germans with Turkish roots. For many, picking one team to support was an easy decision.
item.dc:creator: Tariq Panja and Rory Smith
item.media:description: The flags in Dortmund were Turkish. The fans? The beer? The chatter? Mainly German.

item.title: Toxic Moonshine Leaves at Least 53 Dead in India’s South
item.description: Consumption of tainted bootleg alcohol has caused several instances of mass deaths in recent years as drinkers seek out illicit liquor to save money or evade the law.
item.dc:creator: Mujib Mashal and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: R. Satish Babu/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Family members performed last rites on Thursday during a funeral for victims who died after consuming toxic bootleg alcohol in India’s Tamil Nadu State.

item.title: Putin Came to Asia to Disrupt, and He Succeeded
item.description: His embrace of North Korea and deal making with Vietnam injected more potential threats into a region already strained by Taiwan tensions and South China Sea clashes.
item.dc:creator: Damien Cave
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Thursday.

item.title: Putin Shows He Can Antagonize the U.S. Far Afield From Ukraine
item.description: His support for North Korea’s military ambitions showed he can inflict pain on the U.S. and its NATO allies in ways beyond aggression in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia in Pyongyang, North Korea, on Wednesday, in a photo released by Russian state media.

item.title: U.S.D.A. Avocado Inspectors Will Start Returning to Mexican Packing Plants
item.description: The inspections in Michoacán, the Mexican state responsible for most avocado exports to the U.S., were suspended last weekend because of security concerns.
item.dc:creator: Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
item.category: Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service

item.title: Israeli Official Describes Secret Government Bid to Cement Control of West Bank
item.description: Israeli judges have long ruled that Israel’s control of the territory is a temporary military occupation and complies with international law. A powerful minister’s recent speech, caught on tape, suggested the government is trying to change that.
item.dc:creator: Natan Odenheimer, Ronen Bergman and Patrick Kingsley
item.media:credit: Avishag Shaar-Yashuv for The New York Times
item.media:description: An Israeli soldier at a guard post in the West Bank, in December.

item.title: As Ukraine Expands Military Draft, Some Men Go Into Hiding
item.description: Fearful that conscription is a one-way ticket to bloody trench warfare, the men spend their days holed up at home to avoid draft officers who roam the streets.
item.dc:creator: Constant Méheut
item.media:credit: Brendan Hoffman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Military officials stopping men in Kyiv, the capital of Ukraine, this month to check whether they have updated their information with the draft office.

item.title: How Britain’s Labour Party Became Electable Again
item.description: In less than five years, the opposition Labour Party has gone from massive defeat to the favorite to win next month’s election. How did they do it?
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.media:description: Keir Starmer, the leader of the Labour Party, campaigning in Southampton, England, on Monday. He has nursed his party’s double-digit polling lead for more than 18 months.

item.title: What the Mood Is Like in Iran Ahead of Presidential Elections
item.description: A special presidential election campaign is featuring blistering attacks on the status quo by conservatives and the lone reformer alike.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Iranian presidential candidates in Valiasr Square in Tehran this month.

item.title: Na Kyung Taek’s Photos Exposed a Bloody Crackdown. His Identity Was a Secret.
item.description: Na Kyung Taek’s photos bore witness — and helped bring international attention — to the military junta’s brutal suppression of a pro-democracy uprising in Gwangju, South Korea, in 1980.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Youngrae Kim for The New York Times
item.media:description: Na Kyung Taek with his photographs at an exhibition about the 1980 Gwangju Democratization Movement, in Gwangju, South Korea, this month.

item.title: After Hajj Deaths, Egypt Suspends Companies That Took Pilgrims to Mecca
item.description: The action against 16 tour companies came as governments look into whether many travelers were not properly registered to make the journey into the desert.
item.dc:creator: Gerry Mullany
item.media:description: Muslim pilgrims shading themselves during the annual hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia last week.

item.title: As War Stretches On, Gaza’s High School Students Put Their Dreams on Hold
item.description: Eight months of war have devastated Gaza’s education system, with schools turned into shelters and major rebuilding needed to make them functional again. Tens of thousands of students are missing their final exams.
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek
item.media:description: A United Nations-run school in Khan Younis, southern Gaza, in May. Most such schools are now being used as shelters.

item.title: Consider the Beach
item.description: With much of the U.S. experiencing a heat wave, let us consider the beach and all its promises and pitfalls.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Amid the Stanley Cup Excitement, Edmonton’s Downtown Struggles
item.description: Edmonton’s mayor says that the issues behind homelessness, opioid overdoses and mental health crises cannot be fixed by cities.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:description: Amarjeet Sohi, the mayor of Edmonton, wants more help from higher levels of government.

item.title: Hezbollah Has Threatened Cyprus. Here’s Why.
item.description: Hassan Nasrallah, Hezbollah’s chief, warned that the armed group would punish the small island nation if it allowed Israel to use its airports and bases to target Lebanon.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: President Nikos Christodoulides of Cyprus in Brussels. He said that his country was “not involved in the war conflicts in any way.”

item.title: Piping Up at the Gates of Dawn
item.description: Astronomers have found the earliest and most distant galaxy yet.
item.dc:creator: Dennis Overbye
item.media:credit: NASA, ESA, CSA, STScI, B. Robertson (UC Santa Cruz), B. Johnson (CfA), S. Tacchella (Cambridge), P. Cargile (CfA)
item.media:description: The newly discovered galaxy, known as JADES-GS-z14-0, emanates light that is 13.5 billion years old.

item.title: Are We Loving Our Pets to Death?
item.description: Pet owners are treating their animal charges ever more like humans. But that isn’t good for pets, or for us, many experts argue.
item.dc:creator: Linda Baker
item.media:description: The proliferation of dog strollers is one sign of a trend in which pets’ lives have become constrained and dependent on humans.

item.title: Iran’s 2024 Presidential Election: What to Know
item.description: Iran will hold a special election later this month to replace former President Ebrahim Raisi, who died in a helicopter crash in May.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson and Alissa J. Rubin
item.media:credit: Arash Khamooshi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Watching a presidential debate on a screen this month in Tehran.

item.title: Gilead Shot Provides Total Protection From HIV in Trial of Young African Women
item.description: An injection given just twice a year could herald a breakthrough in protecting the population that has the highest infection rates.
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Nolen
item.media:description: A self-test for H.I.V. in Harare, Zimbabwe. The every-six-months injection was found to provide better protection than the current oral drug for what’s called pre-exposure prophylaxis, also taken as a daily pill.

item.title: UN Chief Warns Israel and Hezbollah of the Risk of a Wider War
item.description: “The people of the region and the people of the world cannot afford Lebanon to become another Gaza,” he said.
item.dc:creator: Ephrat Livni
item.media:description: Secretary General António Guterres, the chief of the United Nations, said on Friday that “the people of the region and the people of the world cannot afford Lebanon to become another Gaza.”

item.title: Hundreds of Hajj Pilgrims Reported Dead Amid Extreme Heat
item.description: Searing heat in Saudi Arabia appeared to at least contribute to many of the deaths.
item.dc:creator: Emad Mekay and Lynsey Chutel
item.media:description: Muslim pilgrims performing the farewell circumambulation or “tawaf,” on Tuesday, circling seven times around the Kaaba, Islam’s holiest shrine, at the Grand Mosque in the holy city of Mecca.

item.title: U.S. Unveils Rules to Curb Investments in Chinese Technology
item.description: The Treasury Department unveiled rules to curb financing of Chinese semiconductors, quantum computers and artificial intelligence systems.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Chinese officials have expressed concern to their U.S. counterparts, including Treasury Secretary Janet L. Yellen, about the new investment curbs.

item.title: Ángeles Flórez Peón, Spanish Civil War’s Last Militiawoman, Dies at 105
item.description: She was revered as an essential guardian of the country’s memory of war and repression long after the Franco dictatorship.
item.dc:creator: Adam Nossiter

item.title: Oil Projects Must Consider Full Climate Impact, Top U.K. Court Rules
item.description: Previously, local council and planning groups in Britain had to weigh only the planet-warming emissions from their own operations.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.media:description: The Ratcliffe-on-Soar Power Station, one of Britain’s few remaining coal-fired stations, in Nottingham, England, in January.

item.title: Israel says it struck a missile launch site in a Gaza ‘humanitarian zone.’
item.dc:creator: Hiba Yazbek

item.title: Euro 2024: Success of Albania and Others Yields Euros for All of Europe
item.description: Eastern European countries who have in recent years lagged behind their continent’s bigger names are having their day in the sun in Germany.
item.dc:creator: Rory Smith
item.media:description: Albania’s prime minister, Edi Rama, center, at his country opening’s game at the Euros.

item.title: 1924: Trial Trip Date Set for Zeppelin
item.description: The giant airship was scheduled to fly across Germany to Denmark, Sweden and back. A flight across the Atlantic to the United States was tentatively planned to follow.
item.dc:creator: The International Herald Tribune

item.title: A Chemical-Sniffing Van Shows How Heat Amps Up Pollution
item.description: In heat waves, chemicals like formaldehyde and ozone can form more readily in the air, according to researchers driving mobile labs in New York City this week.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Mobile labs that measure airborne pollutants drove around New York City and New Jersey during the recent heat wave.

item.title: Amid Gaza War, Netanyahu Feuds With Military, His Coalition and Washington
item.description: As the Israeli prime minister’s allies pull him in multiple, contradictory directions, he has publicly focused on his conflict with the Biden administration.
item.dc:creator: Shashank Bengali
item.media:description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at the Knesset, Israeli parliament, in Jerusalem this month.

item.title: Swiss Court Convicts U.K.’s Richest Family of Exploiting Domestic Staff
item.description: A Swiss criminal court handed prison sentences to members of the Hinduja family for exploiting domestic workers at their villa in Geneva.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:description: Prakash Hinduja, pictured in 2016, and other members of his family were acquitted of human trafficking.

item.title: Well Beyond the U.S., Heat and Climate Extremes Are Hitting Billions
item.description: People all over the world are facing severe heat, floods and fire, aggravated by the use of fossil fuels. The year isn’t halfway done.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:description: Rescuers carried a heat-stricken patient during the hajj pilgrimage in Saudi Arabia on Sunday.

item.title: How to Transport a Giant Valuable Artwork in Australia
item.description: It takes a big truck, a convey of safety vehicles, good planning and a cool nerve.
item.dc:creator: Julia Bergin
item.media:description: The sculpture “Ouroboros,” by the artist Lindy Lee, is craned into position in front of the National Gallery of Australia in Canberra on Wednesday.

item.title: Friday Briefing
item.description: Vladimir Putin’s threat to arm North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin as he visited Hanoi, Vietnam, on Thursday.

item.title: In Japan, These Women Want to Opt Out of Motherhood More Easily
item.description: A lawsuit challenges the onerous requirements for getting sterilized, calling the regulations paternalistic and a violation of women’s constitutional rights.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Kiuko Notoya
item.media:credit: Noriko Hayashi for The New York Times
item.media:description: Kazane Kajiya, left, and Hisui Tatsuta, right, are suing the Japanese government over a law that makes sterilization all but impossible for single, childless women.

item.title: Amazon Says It Will Stop Using Plastic Pillows in Shipments
item.description: They’ll be replaced in North America with paper packing, eliminating some 15 billion pillows a year. Plastic film is a major pollutant.
item.dc:creator: Hiroko Tabuchi
item.media:description: Plastic film is one of the most common forms of marine plastic litter, scientists say.

item.title: Friday Briefing: Vladimir Putin Visits Vietnam
item.description: Also, a rift in Israel over the war in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin as he visited Hanoi, Vietnam, on Thursday.

item.title: Putin Threatens to Arm North Korea, Escalating Tension With West Over Ukraine
item.description: The Russian leader issued the warning at the end of a trip to Asia, during which he signed a mutual defense pact with North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un.
item.dc:creator: Paul Sonne
item.media:description: Portraits of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and North Korea’s leader, Kim Jong-un, on Wednesday in Pyongyang, in a photograph released by Russian state media.

item.title: Attack of Jewish Girl Spurs Tensions Over Antisemitism in France
item.description: An attack on a 12-year-old Jewish girl is inflaming an already tense and divisive situation.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Lyon, France, on Wednesday protesting antisemitism and an alleged attack on a 12-year-old girl outside Paris.

item.title: Monkeys in Puerto Rico Got Nicer After Hurricane Maria
item.description: Macaques, reeling from a hurricane, learned by necessity to get along, a study found. It’s one of the first to suggest that animals can adapt to environmental upheaval with social changes.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer
item.media:description: Rhesus macaques on Cayo Santiago, P.R., in October 2017, just weeks after Hurricane Maria swept through.

item.title: Butterflies Are in Decline. New Research Points to Insecticides.
item.description: Agricultural insecticides were a key factor, according to a study focused on the Midwest, though researchers emphasized the importance of climate change and habitat loss.
item.dc:creator: Catrin Einhorn
item.media:credit: Don Campbell/The Herald-Palladium, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Monarch butterflies in St. Joseph, Mich. U.S. wildlife officials are weighing whether to place monarchs on the endangered species list.

item.title: Climate Protesters Arrested After Spraying Stonehenge With Orange Paint
item.description: Two climate protesters sprayed the powder onto the ancient stones on Wednesday, as the Summer Solstice was to be celebrated at the English site, a popular destination on the longest day of the year.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins and Claire Moses
item.media:credit: Just Stop Oil, via Associated Press
item.media:description: An image taken from a video shows orange powder paint on several stone monoliths at Stonehenge on Wednesday.

item.title: U.S. Will Redirect Deliveries of Patriot Missiles to Ukraine
item.description: A White House spokesman said Ukraine had a critical need for the air defense systems. But the United States has only a limited supply.
item.dc:creator: Erica L. Green and John Ismay
item.media:description: German and Ukrainian troops with Patriot missile batteries in Mecklenburg, Germany, last week. The weapon is the most advanced Western air defense system provided to Ukraine so far.

item.title: Qaeda Commander at Guantánamo Bay Is Sentenced for War Crimes
item.description: A U.S. military jury decided on a 30-year prison term. But under a plea deal, the prisoner’s sentence will end in 2032.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Dutch Leader Mark Rutte Is Poised to Become NATO Chief
item.description: Mark Rutte, the Netherlands’ prime minister, is expected to be elected as the head of the military alliance after Romania’s candidate dropped out.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Rutte of the Netherlands speaking to the news media during a summit focused on Ukraine in Lucerne, Switzerland, last week.

item.title: 3 Takeaways From Putin’s Trip to Vietnam
item.description: The state visit by President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia to Vietnam had a very different backdrop than his trip to North Korea, as Hanoi has deepened ties with Washington.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee and Paul Sonne
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia with President To Lam of Vietnam at the Presidential Palace in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Thursday.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Growing Rift With Israel’s Military Raises Questions About Gaza War’s Future
item.description: Their tensions, which have grown quietly for months, reached a new peak this week when the military’s chief spokesman, Rear Adm. Daniel Hagari, made unusually blunt comments.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Boxerman
item.media:description: Protesters against Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel near his private house in Caesarea, Israel, on Thursday.

item.title: Russia and North Korea’s Defense Pact Is a New Headache for China
item.description: The treaty raises the risk of confrontation in the region and could prompt the United States and its allies to bolster their military presence on China’s periphery.
item.dc:creator: David Pierson and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Associated Press
item.media:description: A photograph provided by North Korean state media showed the North Korean leader, Kim Jong-un, and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia after signing a treaty in Pyongyang on Wednesday.

item.title: Russia and North Korea’s Defense Pact Is a Told-You-So Moment in Asia
item.description: While the agreement rattled officials in South Korea and Japan, the two U.S. allies in recent years have been expecting growing security challenges from North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Motoko Rich and Choe Sang-Hun
item.media:credit: The Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A photograph released by North Korean state media showing North Korea’s leader Kim Jong Un, right, and Russia’s President Vladimir Putin, left, in Pyongyang, North Korea, during a visit this week.

item.title: Who Is Ibrahim al-Organi, Accused of Charging Palestinians to Escape Gaza?
item.description: Ibrahim al-Organi has close connections with the Egyptian government, diplomats say, and he has multiple business interests in Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee, Emad Mekay and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Fatma Fahmy for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ibrahim al-Organi, chairman of Organi Group, in Cairo this month.

item.title: When the Only Escape From War in Gaza Is to Buy a Way Out
item.description: For many Palestinians, securing approval to exit the territory is possible only after raising thousands of dollars to pay middlemen or an Egyptian company.
item.dc:creator: Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Abed Rahim Khatib/Picture Alliance, via Getty Images
item.media:description: Palestinians with foreign passports at the Rafah border crossing in February. The Israeli military launched an offensive against Hamas in Rafah and took over the crossing there, leading to its closure in May. It has yet to reopen.

item.title: Will Copa América Be Messi’s Last Time Representing Argentina in Soccer?
item.description: Lionel Messi had said the 2022 World Cup, which his country won, was his last. Will the Copa América soccer tournament be his goodbye?
item.dc:creator: Daniel Politi, James Wagner and Sarah Pabst
item.media:credit: Sarah Pabst for The New York Times

item.title: How Architecture Became One of Ukraine’s Essential Defenses
item.description: An exhibition in downtown Manhattan showcases more than a dozen grass-roots efforts to rebuild war-stricken cities.
item.dc:creator: Jason Farago

item.title: Seafaring Nomads Settle Down Without Quite Embracing Life on Land
item.description: Indonesia’s Bajo people, who once spent most of their lives in boats or offshore huts, are adopting more sedentary habits, but without forsaking their deep connection to the sea.
item.dc:creator: Muktita Suhartono and Ulet Ifansasti

item.title: Thursday Briefing
item.description: Russia and North Korea pledge mutual defense.
item.dc:creator: Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Vladimir Putin and Kim Jong-un in Pyongyang, North Korea, yesterday, in a photograph released by Russian state media.

item.title: Is Hamas Bound by International Law? What to Know.
item.description: The armed Islamist group committed war crimes on Oct. 7, experts say, and continues to do so by holding hostages.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: A rally in Jerusalem in April calling for the release of hostages held by Hamas. Hostage-taking is a war crime.

item.title: Putin’s Presidential Planes: What We Know
item.description: The Kremlin clings to Soviet-designed aircraft even as Russia’s commercial carriers opt for Western planes.
item.dc:creator: Eve Sampson
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin and the plane he used to travel to North Korea, in a photograph released by Russian state media, on Wednesday.

item.title: Ecuador Hit by Nationwide Blackout
item.description: The public works minister said the power outage had been caused by the failure of a key transmission line. Within hours, power had begun to be restored to the nation of 18 million.
item.dc:creator: José María León Cabrera and Genevieve Glatsky

item.title: Thursday Briefing: Russia and North Korea’s Defense Pledge
item.description: Also, the challenges of getting aid into Gaza.
item.dc:creator: Amelia Nierenberg
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:credit: Korean Central News Agency, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, North Korea’s leader, and President Vladimir Putin yesterday in an image released by the North’s state media.
